context: <b5_0>Stressful life experiences<b5_0/> may be a cause of memory loss as a person ages. Glucocorticoids that are released during stress damage neurons that are located in the hippocampal region of the brain. Therefore, <a1_0>the more stressful situations that someone encounters,<a1_0/> the more susceptible they are to memory loss later on. <a0_0><b4_0><b7_0>The CA1 neurons found<b7_0/> in the <b8_0>hippocampus<b8_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> are destroyed due to glucocorticoids decreasing the release of glucose and the reuptake of glutamate. This <a3_0>high level of extracellular glutamate allow calcium to enter NMDA receptors<a3_0/> which in return kills neurons. Stressful life experiences can also cause <a2_0><b6_0>repression of memories where a person moves an unbearable memory to the unconscious mind<b6_0/><a2_0/>. This directly relates to traumatic events in one's past such as kidnappings, being prisoners of war or sexual abuse as a child.
